metadata.title: Machine learning techniques for investigative reporting | by Techjournalist | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Machine learning techniques for investigative reporting
metadata.description: When you think of machine learning (ML) in journalism the examples you hear are often daring. Some are really complex and tailored to very specific use-cases. Machine-learning models can, for…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: achine-learning models can, for example, be used for reporters to identify business plans, financial statements or tax returns
open-source satellite data for your investigative reporting
how to install R on Mac OC and Windows
West Midlands Police offender prediction model

all_paragraphs: When you think of machine learning (ML) in journalism the examples you hear are often daring. Some are really complex and tailored to very specific use-cases. Machine-learning models can, for example, be used for reporters to identify business plans, financial statements or tax returns among the 200,000 documents that were leaked to the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (other concepts here).

Examples like these are dazzling. But the problem is they are not really helpful for someone who is just starting out. To explore the usefulness of machine learning in data journalism we need to start at a more basic level. This tutorial will begin at that level and hopefully show how to make ML work for you as a journo.

Why this tutorial? Last year’s tutorial on ‘open-source satellite data for your investigative reporting’ was such a hit, this one follows a similar approach on machine learning. Three sections, starting simple and getting more complex.

We take a look at Machine Learning and feature selection (an explainer of feature selection here). The goal is to help you in the process of analyzing data in an automated fashion. It’s less about making wild predictions. Sounds a bit counterproductive? You will see soon how it can be useful in data investigations.

Before we start I want to stress that I am not an expert, merely an enthusiast. I used some of these techniques in my reporting, to really just to make my life easier. There is a whole different universe out there of data-science complexity. We will only scratch the surface and make it practical and useful
You’ll need R installed on your Laptop:
=> Here is how to install R on Mac OC and Windows.
=> How to install R-Studio, the integrated development environment for R.

We will show you how to do feature selection for classification and regression tasks. Data scientists use it all the time to improve the performance of their models while optimizing training time. But here we care less about that. Much more interesting to us and our readers is what makes our data tick. In a few examples, we show you how to answer questions like ‘what made certain demographics in our data vote for Brexit?’ (part 1), ‘what influences ozone readings the most?’ (part 2) and ‘what characteristics make people earn more (and) do we find traces of bias in our data?’ (part 3).
Amanda Cox’s story is a prime example. She used it in her reporting on the US election results for the New York Times.
Another example here is by Stefano Ceccon. He built a UK election Classification Tree (read his post here) for the Times Data Team.
A couple of years ago I used the R-Studio svg output function to draft a visualization for an FT consumer investigation on Chinese iPhone buying habits.

Decision tree models are popular among journalists because they are simple in nature and easier to explain to the readers. Some call them intuitive. Why intuitive? Some say they are similar to how humans make decisions in regards to classification. If a person knew all about the probabilities in the data, he or she would act similarly. Other model types for regression and classification tasks can be very different from this. Decision trees’ graphical output is also helpful to pitch to editors. We saw some examples above.

Some of the shortcomings of decision tree models right at the start: Their predictive accuracy can be lower compared to other model types. Also, small alterations in the data could cause significant changes in the final tree which makes them less robust. In our Random Forrest coding example further down we will show how to overcome this by aggregating many trees in a single model instead of just one. There are also methods like bagging and boosting that can help your model.

We will use a dataset on UK constituencies to investigate what factors have contributed to the UK’s Brexit vote. We consider various age and voting demographics. We want to know which columns are most predictive for the vote.

I merged census data with data on the 2016 Brexit referendum. Now, imagine this dataset — with its mighty 32 columns — lands on your desk. Your editor asks you to investigate which demographics your subsequent reporting should pay close attention to.
What is most predictive for the leave vote?

The main endpoint of interest here is whether constituencies voted leave or not. So binary classification. ‘Leave.percent’ takes on the factor value ‘Leave’ if the vote share was higher then 50 per cent or ‘remain’ if lower.
Let’s load the data into your R-studio environment with the following code.
A taster of the kind of variables we have in the data:

Now we need a model. It’s a classification task. To decide whether ‘Leave’ or ‘Remain’. So we choose a decision tree model. It’s one of the most widely used and practical methods for supervised learning (short explainer here). To fit a decision tree model we use the rpart package (rpart package’s vignette).
rpart is only one option for creating ‘recursive partitioning and regression trees’ in R. The general format to run this is (don’t run this):

The first argument of the function is a model formula, with the ∼ (tilde) symbol standing for “is modeled as”. Left to the tilde symbol we tell the model the outcome variable. In our case “Percent.Leave” (this is ‘Leave’ or ‘Remain’). To the right, we name all the variables that we want the model to consider.

Because we want to explore what’s most important for ‘Percent.Leave’, we throw all the other 31 variables/columns at the model. We do this with “Percent.Leave ~.’” (the dot is short for ‘all other variables’ in the data. It saves us work because we don't have to write out all the variables in the data: ‘Percent.Leave ~Type + Code + All.Residents + Age.0.to.4 + Age.10.to.14….’.

We need to split the data into two sets. We will check on the accuracy later. We apply a 70:30 split for our test and training data (this is not set in stone, but the general approach. Some people disagree here). The Training set [Brexit_train] is, as you may guess, for training the model. The test set [Brexit_test] is a dummy production environment to test predictions, evaluate the accuracy and conditions.
Now after loading the packages, let’s build. Our Brexit_model below:
On your R-Studio console, you should now see the statistics for all splits.
Let’s visualize our decision tree with rpart.plot (vignette here):

We can alter our decision tree visualization for a more compelling and telling presentation. One option is the ggparty package, using ggplot under the hood (curtesy to the new ggparty package creators Martin Borkovec and Niyaz Madin, also check Luis Verde Arregoitia’s post on the matter).
The good thing about this representation is that we get explicit data on the numbers of observations at the nodes level and the relevant values in the predictors that define the splits (Arregoitia).
From both visualizations above we can already gather that type as well as the one specific age demographic matters more than the other 29 columns.
Pruning the decision tree means to tinker with the CP argument in our decision tree rpart model. We want to reduce the cross-validated error. To get the optimal CP we use plotcp to plot it.
printcp and plotcp reveal the cross-validation error for each nsplit and can be used to ‘prune the tree’. The one with the lowest cross-validated error (xerror) is the optimal value of CP.
The optimal complexity parameter (CP) value is in the row with the lowest xerror value.
We update our base model accordingly:
With our pruned tree model in place let’s calculate the accuracy of the tree. Remember, we test on unseen test data which we put aside earlier:
I am happy with my accuracy of 92 per cent. What’s your?

But what if we want to quickly know which variables are most important in your trained rpart decision tree model? We can simply fetch the variable.importance argument and visualize it with ggplot. It could be the only part the editor is really interested in when deciding whether to commission the story to you or not.

Ahh! We see that for our model type (Wales/England or Scotland) and the age demographics of 25 to 34-year-olds bear some of the greatest ‘signal’. In itself not groundbreaking news. But see it in the context of speed of your next analysis with hundreds of columns. Your own data exploration process now uses merely a few lines of code to tell your editor what’s in the box of data.
Boruta approach: Decide which feature to ditch and which to keep:

An alternative feature selection approach is using Boruta and the R package with the same name. ‘Boruta’ can be used to decide whether variables are important or not. It’s a feature selection algorithm based on Random Forrest model (an elaborate example follows shortly).
Fun fact: the name Boruta comes from a demon in Slavic mythology who allegedly dwelled in pine forests. Not impressed? More in this post.

Great! There you have your highly important features on the right. It is nice that the boxplot also shows you outliers, the min, max, first and third quartile in bright green, the median as well as the interquartile range (info on boxplots here).

If you got numeric data to analyze and maybe predict, one option are linear models (lm, an explainer here). We can use it to carry out regression tasks but also for single stratum analysis of variance and analysis of covariance. Relative importance serves us here as an approach to decide which variables have the greatest value for our investigation.
First, we read in ozone level data into R (courtesy to Selva Prabhakaran’s GitHub account).

Now, because all our columns are numeric data we can run a correlation plot to see which columns correlate. You can use the PerformanceAnalytics package for that (but there are a bunch of others, too).

Let’s say we are interested in Ozone level as an outcome variable. From the plot we can already see which features correlate with Ozone_reading. So which of the numeric variables (as opposed to categorical variables previously in the Brexit data) affect ozone level the most?
Using calc.relimp {relaimpo}, the relative importance of variables fed into a lm model, we can determine the relative percentage:

Our model suggests that ‘Temperature_ElMonte’ is relatively speaking more important than ‘Temperature_Sandburg’ (despite a slightly higher correlation coefficient in our correlation plot). From here you can start more conventional data-driven reporting and investigate why this variable comes out top.

In a recent investigation, I checked whether West Midlands Police offender prediction model could be potentially suffering from racial bias by including controversial datasets in the training model. Running a Random Forrest may help you to spot the bias in data used in a law enforcement data model.

Below we see a list of predictors most important to the model by West Midlands Police force. If you run an investigation on possibly controversial models, I’d recommend asking data scientists to disclose their feature importance. It could lead to valuable reporting.

For our purposes, we will use a mundane dataset on peoples’ demographics and wages. But this kind of data could be from a leak or a data breach. Our data lists various demographics for more than 8,000 individuals (it’s a dataset commonly used to train models). Let’s assume one whistleblower emails this data to you. Perhaps it's from a controversial entity you are investigating. Your editor asks you to check the drivers behind peoples’ wages. Are there any legitimate claims for bias?
In the INCOME dataset, we have 14 variables (including gender, MARITAL.STATUS etc.).

We will build a Random Forrest model to classify for INCOME class. Then check on feature importance. We will also optimize our model and run it against a conventional decision tree model (similar to the first part of this tutorial on Brexit data. Which one performs better?).
Let’s load in the data and shuffle it. Then replace NAs (empty cells):
We run a plain Random Forrest model with default parameters in place. Now to the juicy part. Which columns are most telling various INCOME categories?

Unsurprisingly, all of the columns contribute some share. But some much more than others. Occupation seems to be the most telling feature, together with age. BTW, this is similar to what researchers at Temple University found on what influences future affluence the strongest. If gender and ethnicity rank high (or low) it raises some interesting questions that we as reporters may want to follow up investigating.
We are not here for that. But it could give you a hook to further investigating biases or unfair treatment of groups.
Other follow up investigating may entail telling which occupations are mentioned most frequently in each income bucket? We created a mode function for that. Do you spot what I see?

Random Forest models run with default parameters as shown above but leave room for improvements. We can fine-tune our model by changing the ‘mtry’ input dial (the number of variables randomly sampled at each stage, at each split). At the same time, we will play with altering the ‘Ntree’ input (the number of trees we grow.).
To make it a bit easier for us we will only have two categories for income classes: One for over 30,000 and one below.
To find the optimal ‘mtry’ value we will loop through each model and check on the accuracy:
Your mtry value is with the highest average accuracy level.
Sidenote on the ‘Ntree’ input: You shouldn’t make it too small to ensure every input row to be predicted at least a few times.

Checking against other models: We do this to see what’s working best. Difference between Decision Tree and Random Forrest models? check below. There are a great number of other model types (check a list of models the caret package can help you with). These are just some of the simpler ones.

With RPART, the package used to model classification and regression trees, we get a tree that is split into different branches by variables. To predict an outcome we followed the splits and predictions for the most frequent outcomes. As shown in the first example, we controlled the number of splits with the help of the bucket parameter.

Random Forest on ther other hand is slightly more advanced. It is meant for also for classification and regression Trees but uses an ensemble learning algorithm to predict results. Random Forest builds multiple decision trees before compiling the results from all the trees which eventually concludes to a final outcome.
Random Forrest model vs. Decision Tree model:
Compare this with your Random Forrest model:
Nice one! Which of your models win?
Well done in completing the tutorial.

There are a number other feature selection techniques. One is called Information value and Weight of evidence. R’s InformationValue package is for binary classification. It provides functions to calculate weights of evidence and information value for categorical variables. There is also MARS from the earth package. It’s for implementing variable importance based on generalized cross-validation (GCV), number of subset models the variable occurs (nsubsets) and residual sum of squares (RSS). Ther is also Step-wise Regression. Let’s say you have large number of predictors (columns > 15), it helps you to split the input data into sections of ten predictors with each chunk holding the responseVar.

We only checked decision trees, lm and Random Forrest models. But there are a wide wide wide variety of other model types. The R caret package provides a practical way to work with many model types in a standard fashion. If you are interested check out its online handbook (here), the models you can use (here) and a neat R cheat sheet (here). Caret is a great resource to get started in other modeling tasks. Good luck.
Datasources and content for the tutorial:

Census data and referendum results data downloaded from the Kaggle website. Link’s here. Some content was inspired by code published by R-statistics.co and Selva Prabhakaran and other authors, such as by this r-blogger posts.
Check our Selva Prabhakaran material. Some valuable stuff on his website. Income. The Ozone datasets were also from Selva Prabhakaran’s Github repo.
On doing similar stuff in Python:
Feature selection with a Random Forest model can be found in this tutorial by Eryk Lewinson.
This tutorial is by Techjournalist, an investigative journalist, for a 2020 London Journocoders meetup event.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Investigative journalist with a technical edge, interested in open source investigations, satellite imgs, R, python, AI, data journalism and injustice
